title: When you put two phones or radios next to each other and start a call between them, they make a loud ringing sound. Why is that? - Quora

response.answer_text: Sounds like you’re referencing an audio/acoustic feedback loop happening. It’s most commonly noted when a microphone is forward of speakers. And you get that squealing sound. What’s happen’s happening is the sound level from the speakers that are making it into the mic is high enough that it would result in an output of the speakers being even higher than what it was when you were speaking, so the first sound that gets made that would result in this happening, you get the squeal. You can either turn down the volume of the speakers, move the mic, or reduce the gain on the mic. In the case of two phones, you’ve got each with a mic and each with speakers feeding back and they can feed off each other, and it can reach a harmonic based on the delay.
Are you talking about feedback, the voice coming out of the earpiece feeds back into the microphone which keeps amplifying the signal until it reaches a loud feedback tone.
